awd_titl_txt: DNA-Protected Silver Clusters for Atomically Precise Nanophotonics and Wiring
awd_abstract_narration:
The project focuses on tiny particles of 10-30 silver atoms that are encapsulated by strands of DNA. These silver 'clusters' glow in colors set by their size and elongated shapes, which are determined by the sequence of the DNA that wraps around the cluster. The project seeks to control the color-determining cluster geometries within new types of nanometer scale, DNA-based materials that employ silver clusters to manipulate light. Potential applications range from cluster signaling of molecular events around the DNA, to biological imaging in the infrared tissue window, to sensing of disease-related DNA. Additionally, the research aims to develop techniques for merging silver clusters into connected patterns on 'scaffolds' built from DNA, for development of nanoscale antennas and wiring to sense and perhaps even manipulate biomolecular events important to life. Broader participation in science and technology is promoted by development of related 'miniclasses' for presentation to high school students who attend the Saturday sessions of the University of California-Santa Barbara's School for Scientific Thought. Transfer students from California Community Colleges (CCC) are sought to participate in the research, with special efforts to reach underrepresented students.

The project aims to develop atomically precise metal cluster photonics using DNA scaffolds to arrange multicolor assemblies of DNA-stabilized silver clusters, 'AgN-DNA', at separations below 10 nm. Efforts to achieve longer, infrared AgN-DNA build on techniques for identifying composition via high-performance liquid chromatography together with high resolution mass spectrometry (MS). Methods to achieve finer, patterned metallization of DNA scaffolds are sought through the approach of anchoring longer silver cluster rods in AgN-DNA onto DNA scaffolds in select geometries. Understanding of the key interactions of silver cations, Ag+, with DNA bases is developed through mass spectroscopic studies of select DNA oligomers and comparison to advanced quantum chemical calculations carried out by international collaborators.  Miniclasses for high school students will be presented at the University of California-Santa Barbara's School for Scientific Thought. In addition, transfer students from California Community Colleges (CCC) are sought to participate in the research, with special efforts to reach underrepresented students.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: 

The thermal and chemical fragility of DNA-based nanomaterials formed by the well known Watson-Crick base pairings limit the settings in which these materials can be used. We investigated employing the silver cation, Ag+, as an agent for more robust, metal-mediated self-assembly achieved simply by adding a readily available silver salt, AgNO3, to aqueous solutions of select, short strands of DNA.  A key issue is the orientation of the paired strands. Watson-Crick pairing produces an antiparallel strand orientation in two-stranded DNA "duplexes". This antiparallel orientation is central to current protocols for DNA nanostructure assembly, which use the familiar hydrogen bonding of Adenine(A) to Thymine(T) and Guanine(G) to Cytosine (C). In optical studies of DNA strands tagged with dye molecules, we found that the silver-mediated pairing rules are entirely different, pairing G to G by G-Ag+-G bridges and C to C by C-Ag+-C bridges. This silver-mediated pairing reverses the strand orientations in duplexes to a parallel, rather than antiparallel, alignment in the studied cases of DNA strands with all G, or all C, bases. Collisional cross section studies, which probe the overall shapes of the Ag+-paired strands, indicated simple linear duplex structures.

In a second set of studies, we investigated the use of sequence manipulation to extend the wavelength range of fluorescent silver clusters, AgN-DNA, into the near-infrared (NIR). The NIR I (650 - 950 nm) and NIR II (1000-1350 nm) spectral ranges are known to be promising for high sensitivity fluorescence-based cell assays and biological imaging, but the needed biocompatible fluorescent probes have been lacking. AgN-DNA form after the addition of a reducing agent to solutions of certain Ag+ paired DNA strands and contain neutral silver atom clusters as well as some remaining cationic (Ag+) silver content. This work involved development of new NIR instrumentation for the rapid optical study of many hundreds of different DNA strands as potential hosts for NIR-emitting AgN-DNA, including a sensitive, fast NIR fluorescence spectrometer for small sample volumes and instrument modifications that enabled the isolation of specific NIR-emitting AgN-DNA for identification of their chemical composition. This work discovered several DNA strands that host new NIR-emitting AgN-DNA and found the longest wavelength AgN-DNA then identified, with peak emission beyond 950 nm which extended into the NIR II window.  We identified the composition of this AgN-DNA as 30 silver atoms, twelve of them neutral, holding two DNA strands together. This is the largest silver content yet identified for an AgN-DNA and extends our previously established correlation of peak wavelength to number of neutral silver atoms deeper into the NIR, at an even number of neutral silver atoms consistent with the expectation for favored cluster sizes at even "magic numbers".

Broader Impacts: 

Our results indicate that more thermally and chemically stable DNA nanomaterials, with new chemical handles for manipulation, may be achievable by combining sturdy, silver-paired zones with parallel strand orientations together with Watson-Crick paired zones composed of antiparallel strand segments. These studies also established that the addition of Ag+ to G-rich DNA converts the biologically important, four-stranded G quadruplex structure into simple parallel stranded duplexes, a finding that may open new routes to understanding and manipulating G-quadruplexes. 

Our studies of AgN-DNA trained graduate and undergraduate students in the development of scientific instruments. The details of the design and implementation of the low cost, high speed instrumentation we developed for rapid studies of small sample volumes at NIR wavelengths were published to provide access to other researchers. Our finding that the DNA sequence can be chosen to favor clusters of increasing size and longer, NIR wavelength fluorescence is promising for further development of biocompatible NIR fluorophores. 

 


Last Modified: 12/02/2021
Modified by: Elisabeth G Gwinn
